Research article Transformations of tungstacyclopentane species in a WOx/SiO2 catalyst: Different pathways generating olefin metathesis active sites Jarosław Handzlik Cracow University of Technology, Faculty of Chemical Engineering and Technology, ul. Warszawska 24, 31-155 Kraków, Poland Cracow University of Technology Faculty of Chemical Engineering and Technology ul. Warszawska 24 Kraków 31-155 Poland Cracow University of Technology, Faculty of Chemical Engineering and Technology, ul. Warszawska 24, 31-155 Kraków, Poland Graphical abstract Surface tungstacyclopentane species can be formed from alkenes and W(IV) oxide species in the industrial WOx/SiO2 catalyst for large scale olefin metathesis. In this work, density functional theory (DFT) studies of various experimentally observed transformations of silica-supported unsubstituted tungstacyclopentane species, leading mainly to the formation of olefin metathesis active sites, have been performed. It is shown that the conversion of square pyramidal tungstacyclopentane to W(VI) butylidene species via 1,4-hydrogen transfer is slightly more kinetically favored than the ring contraction to α-methyl-substituted tungstacyclobutane through W(VI) butenyl hydride intermediate. In the case of tungstacyclopentane species with the trigonal bipyramidal geometry, the ring contraction can also occur in a single step. Ethene insertion into the secondary W-C bond of the α-methyl-substituted tungstacyclobutane, giving γ-methyl-substituted tungstacyclohexane species, has also been examined. The activation barriers of the tungstacyclopentane transformations can be reduced by about 50 kJ mol−1 if a surface silanol group adjacent to the metal site takes part. Initially, W(VI) butyl species are formed, which can then convert to W(VI) butylidene species, α-methyl-substituted tungstacyclobutane or 1-butene together with the monooxo W(IV) species. The proposed silanol-assisted transformations of surface tungstacyclopentane species yielding olefin metathesis active sites may compete with other reported activation mechanisms involving a silanol group. Keywords Tungsten oxide Silica Tungstacyclopentane Ring contraction Active site Alkene metathesis DFT Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Light olefins such as ethene, propene and butene are key feedstocks in the chemical industry. By reason of the increasing demand especially for propene, more and more attention has been paid to on-purpose technologies, like olefin metathesis [1–3]. The large scale olefins conversion technology (OCT) for propene production from ethene and butene can be combined with steam cracking or fluid catalytic cracking (FCC) in order to increase the propene output in relation to ethene. Propene is also produced solely from ethene, via ethene dimerization to 1-butene, followed by isomerization of 1-butene to 2-butene and cross metathesis of ethene and 2-butene [1–3]. In the OCT process, the WOx/SiO2 catalyst is applied [1–4], which is activated in situ, similar to other supported metal oxide catalysts for olefin metathesis. Metal alkylidene sites, required for the commonly accepted carbene mechanism [5,6], are formed from the surface metal oxide species upon contact with alkene [4,7–15]. In the WOx/SiO2 system, isolated dioxo and monooxo W(VI) species were observed [11,13,14,16,17]. The former [11–14,18] or both species [19] were proposed as the precursors of the active sites for olefin metathesis. Several activation mechanisms were considered for the heterogeneous olefin metathesis catalysts [4,7,8,10–12,20–30] and most of them involves reduced metal species. In the case of the WOx/SiO2 catalyst, some authors postulated reduction of the dioxo W(VI) species to monooxo W(IV) species by alkene [10,14]. The latter would be further converted to active tungsten alkylidene species. Such a scenario is supported by the results reported for well-defined W(VI) oxo species on silica, which are inactive in olefin metathesis at mild conditions, but after their reduction to W(IV) the system exhibits high activity [22,25]. Metallacyclopentane complexes were suggested many years ago as intermediates in the formation of metal alkylidene species [31,32]. Later, based on the results obtained for tantalum complexes, contraction of the metallacyclopentane ring to metallacyclobutane was proposed [33]. The possibility of the activation of the silica-supported W(IV) species via the oxidative coupling-ring contraction mechanism (Scheme 1 ) was indicated by 1H and 13C solid state NMR detection of surface tungstacyclopentane and tungstacyclobutane complexes [22,25]. Some other experimental works did not confirm that contraction of the tungstacyclopentane ring is an efficient route for initiating olefin metathesis [24,34]. However, recently, much attention has been paid to the possibility of transforming tungstacyclopentane complexes into metal alkylidene species [35–38]. It was shown that photochemical ring contraction of unsubstituted tungstacyclopentane complexes in solution occurs, yielding W(VI) methylidene complexes and propene (Scheme 1) or unsubstituted tungstacyclobutane complexes in the presence of ethene [35]. It was also demonstrated that a tungstacyclopentane complex in solution having one secondary W-C bond can form and ring-contract thermally [38]. In the case of unsubstituted tungstacyclopentane species on silica, both photochemical and thermal ring contraction were observed and the catalytic cycle of direct conversion of ethene to propene was proposed [36]. Inactive tungstacyclohexane species were also detected, most likely resulting from ethene insertion into the secondary W-C bond in tungstacyclobutane (Scheme 1). Computational chemistry tools complement experimental methods and allow for a better understanding of the mechanistic aspects of surface reactions. Although some theoretical studies on the formation of the olefin metathesis active sites from supported metal oxides were reported [26,28–30,39–45], the potential transformations of the surface metallacyclopentane species were usually neglected. The only exception is the 1,4-hydrogen shift mechanism leading directly to metal alkylidene species (Scheme 1). This pathway, previously proposed for a tungstacyclopentane complex in solution [46], was calculated for molybdacyclopentane [29] and tungstacyclopentane [30] species on silica. The above-mentioned experimental results demonstrating that tungstacyclopentane complexes, including surface species, can transform into alkylidene species [35–38] were the inspiration for this computational work. The aim is to thoroughly investigate the possible mechanisms of transformations of tungstacyclopentane species on silica that may lead to the generation of olefin metathesis active sites. Recently, it was proposed [29,30] that surface silanol groups may play a key role in reduction of Mo(VI) and W(VI) oxide species on silica by alkene to Mo(IV) and W(IV). Silanol-assisted activation of the Mo(IV) and W(IV) species to form metal alkylidene sites was also postulated [24–26,29,30]. However, to the best of my knowledge, the participation of surface hydroxyl groups in the transformations of metallacyclopentane species has not been taken into account so far, even though the latter can easily be formed from Mo(IV) or W(IV) species and alkenes [22,24,25,29,30,36]. In this work, a computational study of the silanol-assisted formation of olefin metathesis active sites from tungstacyclopentane species have been performed for the first time. 2 Computational models and methods A periodic model of the monooxo W(IV) species on amorphous silica [47] (Fig. 1 ) was prepared based on the previously proposed structure of the isolated digrafted dioxo W(VI) species under dehydrated conditions [30,48]. The latter were reported to dominate in the calcinated WOx/SiO2 systems with low tungsten loadings [13,16,17] and their reduction should result in formation of the digrafted monooxo W(IV) species [10,14,30]. The unit cell contains 27 Si atoms and its dimensions are a = 12.77 Å, b = 17.64 Å, c = 25.17 Å, including approximately 15 Å of vacuum. Based on this model, other surface species and a transition state for a selected reaction pathway were computed to enable comparison with the results of cluster calculations. The geometry optimization was carried out with the PBE0 method [49] implemented in the Vienna Ab Initio Simulation Package (VASP 6) [50]. The hybrid PBE0 functional was shown to perform well in predicting geometrical parameters of transition metal complexes [51–55], including compounds containing 5d metals [52]. For valence electrons, a plane-wave basis set was used with a cutoff energy of 400 eV. Atomic cores are described with the projector-augmented wave (PAW) method [56]. For tungsten the PAW is built with 14 electrons in the valence. The Γ point was applied in the Brillouin zone integration. The transition state structure was determined using the improved dimer method [57,58] and verified by analysis of the imaginary vibrational mode. The Hessian matrix was calculated by the finite difference method. The tungsten atom and its neighbors, including the third coordination sphere, were included in the Hessian matrix. Single point energies were corrected for dispersion interactions according to the DFT-D3(BJ) approach [59,60]. A cluster model of the monooxo W(IV) species 1 (Fig. 1) was built [30], which corresponds to the periodic structure. The dangling bonds are saturated with hydrogen atoms that replace the removed silicon atoms, forming hydroxyl groups at the cluster periphery. This model, representing isolated W(IV) species not interacting with surface silanols, was the starting structure in the exploration of the non-silanol-assisted mechanisms. For comparison reasons, an analogous but larger cluster model of the monooxo W(IV) species 1 was also developed (Fig. S1, Supplementary data) and used in selected calculations. Another cluster model of the monooxo W(IV) species (12, Fig. 1) includes adjacent hydroxyl groups. It is based on the initial β-cristobalite structure, often used to represent the silica surface [29,30,61–67], but after full geometry optimization the amorphous nature of the support is reflected. Model 12 was the starting structure in the study of the silanol-assisted mechanisms. The PBE0 functional in combination with the def2-SVP basis set [68] was applied for the geometry optimization of the cluster models and molecules. Vibrational frequencies were computed in the harmonic oscillator approximation to confirm local minima or first-order saddle points and to determine thermal corrections to energy and Gibbs energy. The transition state structures were also verified by the IRC method [69–71]. Single point energy calculations were performed for the optimized structures using the PBE0 functional and def2-TZVPP basis set [68]. An overall good accuracy of the PBE0 method in predicting the energetics of transition metal compounds was reported [72–74]. The spin-restricted and spin-unrestricted formalism was used for the closed-shell and open-shell systems, respectively. For the models of W(IV) species the ground state is singlet (Table S1, Supplementary data). Since all other models represent closed-shell W(VI) species, only singlet reaction pathways were considered. The total Gibbs energy for a given system is estimated as the sum of the PBE0/def2-TZVPP single point energy, DFT-D3(BJ) dispersion correction and the thermal correction, including the zero point energy. The total energies are calculated in the same way. The reaction pathways are presented in terms of relative Gibbs energies at T = 373.15 K, which corresponds to the experimental conditions of the observed thermal transformations of tungstacyclopentane complexes (358–373 K) [36,38]. Additionally, the energy profiles (T = 373.15 K) of the reaction pathways are shown in the Supplementary data (Figs. S2–S5). Cluster calculations were performed with the Gaussian 09 set of programs [75]. For the large cluster models the Gaussian 16 package was applied [76] with the same settings as in Gaussian 09. For the graphic presentation of the structures, the GaussView 6.0 software was used [77]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Non-silanol-assisted transformations of tungstacyclopentane species The reaction pathway between ethene and the monooxo W(IV) species on silica leading to the formation of tungstacyclopentane species, as well as their possible subsequent transformations, are shown in Fig. 2 . Tungstacyclopentane complexes form readily, as do molybdacyclopentane species [29]. Ethene complex 2 can convert to trigonal bipyramidal (TBP) tungstacyclopentane 4a through bis(ethene) complex 3. Subsequent pseudorotation of the tungstacyclopentane ring gives stable conformer 4b with the square pyramidal (SP) geometry. The low overall activation Gibbs energy for these reactions (40 kJ mol−1, related to 2) increases with temperature due to the entropic effect caused by the addition of the second ethene molecule. For example, at T = 673 K the predicted activation barrier reaches 100 kJ mol−1 [30], which however still allows the formation of the tungstacyclopentane species. The latter may be in thermodynamic equilibrium with the ethene complex 2, depending on the temperature [30] and ethene pressure. This is consistent with the reported detection of olefin π-complexes and tungstacyclopentane species on silica [22,24]. 1,4-hydrogen shift to give W(VI) butylidene complex 7 (Fig. 2) is the most kinetically favored pathway for the transformation of the metallacyclopentane species to olefin metathesis active sites, in line with previously reported computational works [29,30,46]. However, the calculated activation Gibbs energy of this step is still quite high, of 196 kJ mol−1. The barrier for hydrogen transfer from the β-carbon in the ring to the tungsten atom, leading to the formation of W(VI) butenyl hydride 5a, is higher by 8 kJ mol−1. After a series of successive conformational rearrangements (5a-5d), W(VI) butenyl hydride can readily convert to α-methyl-substituted tungstacyclobutane 6a with the SP geometry. A direct ring contraction of the TBP tungstacyclopentane 4a to the tungstacyclobutane species 6a via 2,1-hydrogen shift is also possible, with an even higher overall barrier (208 kJ mol−1), determined by the energy of the more stable SP tungstacyclopentane species 4b. Finally, TBP tungstacyclopentane 4a can directly transform to W(VI) butenyl hydride 5b, which requires overcoming a barrier higher by another 3 kJ mol−1. Thus, the calculated overall activation Gibbs energies for the 1,4-hydrogen shift and various ring-contraction pathways are in the narrow range of 196–211 kJ mol−1 (related to 4b). Taking into account the limited accuracy of the DFT methods and the influence of the geometry and location of the metal site on its reactivity [29,30,78–85], these mechanisms may compete with each other. The selected tungsten species and the rate-determining transition state in the pathway leading to the formation of W(VI) butylidene 7 (Fig. 2) were also calculated using the periodic model (Fig. 1) and the large cluster model (Fig. S1, Supplementary data). The relative energies of the corresponding compounds and the activation energies obtained with the periodic and cluster approximations hardly differ, by few kJ mol−1 (Table S2, Supplementary data). The same can be observed for activation energies calculated using the standard and large cluster model (Table S3, Supplementary data), while the discrepancy in relative energies is slightly larger, but still insignificant, ranging from a few to 13 kJ mol−1. The relative energies are more influenced by whether or not the dispersion correction is included, but this has little effect on the activation energy for this pathway (Tables S2 and S3, Supplementary data). A high-energy transition state between the bis(ethene) complex 3 and W(VI) butenyl hydride has also been localized (Fig. S6, Supplementary data), making this pathway very unlikely, although the α-methyl-substituted tungstacyclobutane 6a could be readily formed in the next step. In addition, a possibility of ethene dimerization to 1-butene was examined as well. Hydrogen transfer to the α-carbon of W(VI) butenyl hydride, leading to 1-butene complex 8, is much less kinetically favored than the transfer to the terminal carbon, resulting in the formation of the α-methyl-substituted tungstacyclobutane 6a (Fig. 2). On the other hand, the 1-butene complex 8 is more thermodynamically stable. Cycloreversion of α-methyl-substituted tungstacyclobutane to give metal alkylidene species first requires two conformational rearrangements (Fig. 3 ). The ring in 6a is puckered down, which is opposite to the typical geometry of the SP metallacyclobutanes [25,36,66,78,79,81,82,86–91], represented by the conformer 6b. (Fig. 4 ). Pseudorotation of the tungstacyclobutane ring in the latter system gives the α-methyl-substituted tungstacyclobutane 6c with the TBP geometry, which can eventually decompose to W(VI) methylidene species 9 and propene or W(VI) ethylidene species 10 and ethene (Fig. 3). Despite many attempts, the cycloreversion transition states were not localized. Based on experimental data, ethene insertion into the secondary W-C bond in α-methyl-substituted tungstacyclobutane on silica was recently postulated [36]. Both SP conformers, 6a and 6b, can undergo this reaction, leading to the formation of γ-methyl-substituted tungstacyclohexane species 11a and 11c with the TBP geometry (Figs. 3 and 4). In the next step, they readily rearrange into the thermodynamically more stable SP conformers, 11b and 11d, respectively. Similar to the tungstacyclobutane conformers 6a and 6b, the corresponding tungstacyclohexane species differ in their ring conformation (Fig. 4). The calculated activation Gibbs energy for ethene insertion is moderate (136 kJ mol−1), suggesting that this thermodynamically favored reaction can occur at about 373 K. The considered reactions of tungsten species on silica are summarized in Scheme 2 . Tungstacyclopentane species, readily generated from the monooxo W(IV) species and ethene, can undergo 1,4-hydrogen transfer to form W(VI) butylidene species, or ring contraction, most likely through W(VI) butenyl hydride intermediate. In both cases, olefin metathesis active sites are obtained. The formation of 1-butene complex is kinetically less favorable. The experimentally observed [36] γ-methyl-substituted tungstacyclohexane species is the most thermodynamically stable by-product. However, even the most kinetically preferred pathways, ultimately leading to W(VI) alkylidene species, require overcoming a Gibbs energy barrier of approximately 200 kJ mol−1, which is much higher than the barriers predicted for silanol-assisted mechanisms (vide infra). 3.2 Silanol-assisted transformations of tungstacyclopentane species The mechanism of tungstacyclopentane formation, calculated for the monooxo W(IV) species 12 (Fig. 5 ), is qualitatively the same as in the case of model 1 (Fig. 2). The differences in energetic parameters between these pathways result from the fact that the W(IV) species represented by models 1 and 12 are located differently on the silica surface. This again confirms that the activity of the surface metal species is influenced by even slight differences in their geometry and surroundings [29,30,78–85]. Nevertheless, the overall activation Gibbs energy of tungstacyclopentane formation is quite low for both pathways (40 and 57 kJ mol−1, related to 2 and 13, respectively). Hence, ethene complex 13 can easily transform to more stable SP tungstacyclopentane 15b via bis(ethene) complex 14 and TBP tungstacyclopentane 15a (Fig. 5). However, the relative stability of ethene complex and tungstacyclopentane species depends on temperature [30]. Hydrogen transfer from the adjacent surface silanol group to the α-carbon of tungstacyclopentane 15b enables the formation of the trigrafted W(VI) butyl complex 16a with a relatively low activation Gibbs energy of 76 kJ mol−1 (Fig. 5). The latter and its conformers 16b-16d are the most stable species along the reaction pathway. Nevertheless, they can transform into α-methyl-substituted tungstacyclobutane 17a, W(VI) butylidene 18 and 1-butene coordinated to the regenerated monooxo W(IV) species 19. In these reactions, a hydrogen atom is transferred from the γ-carbon, α-carbon and β-carbon of the butyl ligand to the W-O-Si bond, respectively, with recovery of the silanol group. Regeneration of the tungstacyclopentane 15b in the reverse reaction requires hydrogen transfer from the terminal carbon of the butyl ligand to the W-O-Si moiety. Interestingly, a well-defined silica-supported dioxo W(VI) alkyl complex was shown to be an active catalyst for olefin metathesis, and surface protonation by the alkyl ligand was proposed as one of the potential activation mechanisms [92]. The predicted activation barriers for the formation of 17a, 18 and 19 differ from each other by only a few kJ mol−1 (Fig. 5), which suggests a kinetic preference: 19 ≥ 18 ≥ 17a. Hence, it can be considered that all these mechanisms are approximately equally probable. The overall activation Gibbs energy for the silanol-assisted transformations of the tungstacyclopentane species (149–154 kJ mol−1, related to 16b or 16d) is about 50 kJ mol−1 lower than the barriers calculated for the corresponding kinetically most favored mechanisms occurring without the participation of the silanol group (196–204 kJ mol−1, related to 4b, Fig. 2). This indicates a role of the surface silanol groups in generation of the active sites for olefin metathesis, similar to other initiation mechanisms reported recently [26,29,30]. In the case of the non-silanol-assisted mechanisms, activation of the tungstacyclopentane species is the rate-determining step (Fig. 2). It requires a hydrogen shift within the ring or from a carbon atom to the tungsten atom to form the much less stable W(VI) butenyl hydride species. In contrast, hydrogen transfer from a nearby silanol group to the tungstacyclopentane ring to generate stable trigrafted W(VI) butyl species occurs much more readily (Fig. 5). Subsequent hydrogen transfer back to the support with formation of the olefin metathesis active site is the rate-determining step, but the conformational flexibility of the butyl ligand prevents activation barriers from being too high. The ability of the silanol group to donate hydrogen to an organic ligand at the metal site, resulting in the formation of an additional bond between the metal and the support, along with the subsequent possibility of silanol regeneration by transfer of another hydrogen from the ligand to the metal-support bond, is a key feature of the silanol-assisted mechanisms. This reversible hydrogen exchange between the silica support and the metal species replaces direct hydrogen shift in the organic ligand or formation of metal hydride, which require overcoming much higher activation barriers. These computational results can also explain why thermal ring contraction of the unsubstituted tungstacyclopentane complex on silica is possible at moderate temperatures, as observed experimentally [36]. The Gibbs activation energy for the conversion of the W(VI) butyl species to W(VI) butylidene 18 (151 kJ mol−1) is within the range of the activations barriers for the analogous transformations of the W(VI) isopropyl species (138–187 kJ mol1) and W(VI) propyl species (141–183 kJ mol−1) at T = 373 K, calculated for several W sites slightly differing in geometry [30]. Silanol-assisted activation of the monooxo W(IV) species via a propene π-complex can directly generate W(VI) isopropyl species [30], which requires overcoming a barrier of 46–100 kJ mol−1 (T = 373 K), depending on the particular W site. This can be compared with the formation of W(VI) butyl species 16a-16d from the monooxo W(IV) species 12 and ethene through tungstacyclopentane species 15a and 15b, characterized by the overall activation Gibbs energy of 76 kJ mol−1 (related to 15b, Fig. 5). Thus, the silanol-assisted activation mechanism involving tungstacyclopentane intermediates may be competitive with the recently reported initiation routes assuming a direct formation of W(VI) alkyl species from W(IV) alkene complex [26,30]. The kinetic preference for a given mechanism may depend on the geometry and location of the metal species, temperature [29,30] and the activating alkene. The results presented in this work correspond to a single W site and do not include a distribution of surface metal species with different distorted structures and activities [81–83]. Compared to the silanol-assisted pathways, the activation of the monooxo W(IV) species by propene via the pseudo-Wittig mechanism is kinetically very unfavorable, with the predicted Gibbs energy barrier of 312 kJ mol−1 (T = 373 K) [30]. This often proposed mechanism [11,12,39–45] is more plausible for W(V) oxo species and dioxo W(VI) species on silica [30]. In the latter case, the calculated barrier is 240 and 208 kJ mol−1 (T = 373 K) for ethene and propene, respectively. A series of rapid conformational rearrangements of the α-methyl-substituted tungstacyclobutane species 17a-17d is followed by cycloreversion giving W(VI) alkylidene sites (Fig. 6 ). 17a, formed directly from W(VI) butyl species 16b, has the SP geometry with the ring puckered down (Fig. 7 ), similar to 6a (Fig. 4). After a conformation change to 17b having the ring puckered up, an additional unusual intermediate 17c has been localized along the reaction pathway. While its geometry can be still described as distorted SP, the C-W-C angle (80.3°) is close to the C-W-C angle in conformer 17d (82.9°) with a distorted TBP geometry. For comparison, the C-W-C angles in 17a and 17b are 65.6° and 65.4°, respectively, similar to those in their counterparts 6a and 6b (63.3° and 64.2°). The calculated routes for the formation of the tungstacyclopentane species and their subsequent silanol-assisted transformations are summarized in Scheme 3 . The surface W(VI) butyl complex, easily formed from tungstacyclopentane, is the key and the same time the most stable species. It can slowly rearrange to W(VI) butylidene, α-methyl-substituted tungstacyclobutane or 1-butene complex, with activation barriers being similar and lower by about 50 kJ mol−1 than in the case of the formation of these products according to the non-silanol-assisted mechanisms (Scheme 2). The price for the higher reactivity of type 12 W(IV) sites (Fig. 1), compared to type 1 sites, is the easier formation of 1-butene, as a product of ethene dimerization. This results in the regeneration of the monooxo W(IV) species, so their activation is necessary again. As ethene insertion into the W-C bond of α-methyl-substituted tungstacyclobutane does not gain from the proximity of a hydroxyl group, one can expect that the activation barriers for the formation of the methyl-substituted tungstacyclohexane species in this case are similar to those calculated for the models without an adjacent silanol group (Fig. 3). 3.3 Structures of tungstacyclopentane species Tungstacyclopentane species can be readily formed from the monooxo W(IV) species and alkene (Figs. 2 and 5), as reported previously [30], and are key intermediates in the mechanisms investigated in this work. Models 4a and 15a (Fig. 8 ) have the TBP geometry, which is more distorted in the second case. The base of the trigonal bipyramid is defined by two α-carbon atoms from the ring and the oxygen atom from the W-O-Si linkage. The second linking oxygen and the oxo ligand are in the apical positions. Interestingly, the structure of 15a can also be described as a distorted SP geometry if the three oxygen atoms bonded to W and one α-carbon from the ring are considered as the base of a square pyramid, while the second α-carbon is the apex. In turn, 4b and 15b are typical tungstacyclopentane complexes with the SP geometry, which is confirmed by the values of the τ parameter [93] close to zero (0.04 and 0.06, respectively). The two α-carbon atoms from the ring and the oxygen atoms from both W-O-Si linkages constitute the base of the pyramid, while the oxo ligand is at the apical position. In Table 1 , selected geometrical parameters of the calculated tungstacyclopentane structures are compared with the reported experimental data for W(O)(C4H8)(OHMT)2 complex having a similar coordination sphere and a geometry intermediate between TBP and SP (τ = 0.44) [94]. However, its geometry appears to be closer to the calculated SP tungstacyclopentane species (4b and 15b), while significantly different from the TBP conformers (4a and 15a). It is seen both for the ring conformation and the W=O bond length. This is consistent with the higher stability of the SP tungstacyclopentane complexes, compared to their TBP conformers, as predicted theoretically in this work and previously [30,38]. 4 Conclusions Computational studies have been carried out on the transformations of tungstacyclopentane species on silica formed from ethene and the monooxo W(IV) species in the WOx/SiO2 catalyst. These reactions are relevant for generation of the active sites for olefin metathesis and most of them were experimentally confirmed for a silica-supported tungstacyclopentane complex [36]. In line with the recently suggested mechanisms [36], W(VI) butenyl hydride may be a key intermediate in the ring contraction of the unsubstituted tungstacyclopentane to give α-methyl-substituted tungstacyclobutane. In the case of the TBP tungstacyclopentane, one-step ring contraction is also possible. Direct formation of W(VI) butylidene species from the SP tungstacyclopentane via 1,4-hydrogen transfer in the ring is slightly more kinetically favored than ring contraction. However, the predicted activation barriers for all of these reactions are relatively high. For the first time, a ring contraction mechanism involving an adjacent surface silanol group has been proposed. The key species in this pathway is the surface W(VI) butyl complex, which can also be converted to the W(VI) butylidene species. The calculated activation Gibbs energy for these transformations, resulting in olefin metathesis active sites, is lower by about 50 kJ mol−1, compared to the corresponding mechanisms without the participation of the silanol group. Another possibility is the formation of 1-butene from the W(VI) butyl site with regeneration of the monooxo W(IV) species. The proposed silanol-assisted transformations of surface tungstacyclopentane species to yield tungstacyclobutane and W(VI) alkylidene sites active in olefin metathesis can compete with other silanol-assisted activation mechanisms recently reported [30]. The kinetic preference for a given activation route may depend on the structure and location of the metal site, temperature [29,30] and substrate. Considering the heterogeneity of the surface metal species [29,30,48,78–85], the olefin metathesis active sites in the WOx/SiO2 catalyst can be formed via different mechanisms operating at the same time. coredata.dc:description: Surface tungstacyclopentane species can be formed from alkenes and W(IV) oxide species in the industrial WOx/SiO2 catalyst for large scale olefin metathesis. In this work, density functional theory (DFT) studies of various experimentally observed transformations of silica-supported unsubstituted tungstacyclopentane species, leading mainly to the formation of olefin metathesis active sites, have been performed. It is shown that the conversion of square pyramidal tungstacyclopentane to W(VI) butylidene species via 1,4-hydrogen transfer is slightly more kinetically favored than the ring contraction to α-methyl-substituted tungstacyclobutane through W(VI) butenyl hydride intermediate. In the case of tungstacyclopentane species with the trigonal bipyramidal geometry, the ring contraction can also occur in a single step. Ethene insertion into the secondary W-C bond of the α-methyl-substituted tungstacyclobutane, giving γ-methyl-substituted tungstacyclohexane species, has also been examined. The activation barriers of the tungstacyclopentane transformations can be reduced by about 50 kJ mol−1 if a surface silanol group adjacent to the metal site takes part. Initially, W(VI) butyl species are formed, which can then convert to W(VI) butylidene species, α-methyl-substituted tungstacyclobutane or 1-butene together with the monooxo W(IV) species. The proposed silanol-assisted transformations of surface tungstacyclopentane species yielding olefin metathesis active sites may compete with other reported activation mechanisms involving a silanol group.
